{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3559372,"name":"Collyn Diamond","username":"123pdrinter","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/123pdrinter/{size}/248529_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-17T16:45:32.426Z","cooked":"

I’ve always been impressed with some teams auto routines - 1690’s crescendo auto, 27’s reefscape auto, the list goes on - and have always wanted to replicate their success and accuracy.

This is my teams first year seriously implementing PhotonVision into our robot, and my pose estimates are always jittery and have high error. Can anyone with more experience point me in the right direction? Whether it just be tuning, or switching to something like a Limelight, any help would be appreciated.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-03-17T16:45:32.426Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":27,"reads":141,"readers_count":140,"score":178.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":495909,"topic_slug":"odomety-with-photonvision-what-are-some-good-practices-for-best-results","display_username":"Collyn Diamond","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":71586,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/odomety-with-photonvision-what-are-some-good-practices-for-best-results/495909/1","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3559408,"name":"John Fogarty","username":"JohnFogarty","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/johnfogarty/{size}/267052_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-17T17:08:57.997Z","cooked":"

You can absolutely get a stable pose from Photonvision. Lots of variables to consider and some of these variables are the same as what you would need to consider for any vision solution.

Start with the camera configuration in the application itself…

What’s your average ambiguity when looking at a tag?
How well calibrated is your camera?
Have you increased your sample count?

How do you tell how well the camera is calibrated? And how do you know your sample count and how to increase it?

We are using the advantagekit talonfx swerve template if that helps.

My suggestions are entirely referring to the Photonvision client.

PhotonVision Documentation

Calibrating Your Camera

To calibrate a camera, images of a Charuco board (or chessboard) are taken. By comparing where the grid corners should be in object space (for example, a corner once every inch in an 8x6 grid) with...

The dashboard view when you have the camera feed open should show an ambiguity value in the table in the bottom right corner.

PhotonVision Documentation

3D Tracking

3D AprilTag tracking will allow you to track the real-world position and rotation of a tag relative to the camera’s image sensor. This is useful for robot pose estimation and other applications lik...

You can definitely achieve great results with PV.
It’s kind of difficult to just give general advice, jittery poses can happen due to many reasons, and general advice is most of the time just too high level or irrelevant, or stuff like that.
That said though, I can recommend checking out a lecture we gave this past summer, it covers some general tips and improvements for odometry & vision. Hope it’ll help!
